org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint

Class MotorJoint

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dyn4j.dynamics.Constraint
      • org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint.Joint
        • org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint.MotorJoint

  • public class MotorJoint
extends Joint
    Represents a motor joint.

    A motor joint uses motors to move two bodies relative to one another.

    This joint is ideal for character movement as it allows direct control of the motion using targets, but yet still allows interaction with the environment. Make one body static to achieve this effect.

    NOTE: The linear and angular targets are relative to body1. Nearly identical to Box2d's equivalent class.

    Since:
    3.1.0
    Version:
    3.1.5
    Author:
    William Bittle
    See Also:
    Box2d

      • shiftCoordinates

        protected void shiftCoordinates(Vector2 shift)
        Description copied from class: Constraint
        Shifts (translates) the coordinates of this constraint.

        Typically this method should not be called directly. Instead use the World.shiftCoordinates(Vector2) method to move the entire world.

        Specified by:
        shiftCoordinates in class Constraint
        Parameters:
        shift - the distance to shift along the x and y axes

      • getLinearTarget

        public Vector2 getLinearTarget()
        Returns the desired linear distance along the x and y coordinates from body1's world center.

        To get the world linear target: 

         joint.getBody1().getWorldVector(joint.getLinearTarget());
        Returns:
        Vector2

      • setLinearTarget

      • getCorrectionFactor

        public double getCorrectionFactor()

        Returns:
        double

      • setCorrectionFactor

        public void setCorrectionFactor(double correctionFactor)
        Sets the correction factor.

        The correction factor controls the rate at which the bodies perform the desired actions.

        A value of zero means that the bodies do not perform any action.

        Parameters:
        correctionFactor - the correction factor in the range [0, 1]

      • getMaximumTorque
